webTitle: Ashes 2019: England v Australia second Test, day four – as it happened

fields.headline: Ashes 2019: England v Australia second Test, day four – as it happened
fields.standfirst: After Australia were bowled out for 250, England suffered a top-order collapse in their second innings and closed out on 96-4 at the end of the fourth day
fields.trailText: After Australia were bowled out for 250, England suffered a top-order collapse in their second innings and closed out on 96-4 at the end of the fourth day
fields.byline: Tanya Aldred , Adam Collins and  Jonathan Howcroft
fields.body:
7.30pm BST

Time to call it a day here, after some of the most gripping sessions of Test cricket I can remember. That Archer to Smith spell, high speed and guile against an outstanding batsman with daemons in his head, will be imprinted on many minds this evening

The horrendous felling of Smith was awful to watch, and thankfully he’s ok. And yet, it may have torn a hole in his protective cocoon that has worked hitherto so well this series. We must watch and wait. And after all that, England’s batsmen batted through a torrid last session. Of course, it could all end in a draw - but don’t miss a ball tomorrow. Phew - time for a stretch. Have a great evening everyone!

Updated at 7.31pm BST

7.20pm BST

And while I remember, thank you so much for all your emails and sorry I couldn’t print them all. One more to finish on, from Matt Redgrave, a thoughtful reply to Damien Edgar’s similarly sensitive mail.

Think its all pretty valid. The Phil Hughes death hasn’t changed the culture over here and we tend not to have high speed bowlers and fast wickets that often, so it is understandable that English cricket hasnt done this thinking. Time to do it now though..Also Archer was 19 when Hughes tragically died. Root as captain should guide him. I’d expect a captain to head over to the Aussie camp and check he’s ok and express concern.

Updated at 7.21pm BST

7.16pm BST

“It was a terrible blow and it looked horrible at the time but thankfully Steve is ok, “ says Justin Langer.

Ian Ward asks whether Smith was ok to come out after his wild slog for four in the eighties and then his change of mind about the review when he was out. Langer reassures us that Smith was fine.

HE then goes on to explain that Smith is one of the few players who doesn’t wear a stem guard on his helmet - his personal choice, he can’t feel comfortable with it.

7.10pm BST

I don’t really know where to start with today. Two sides going at each other with everything, divided by a piece of RICE paper, with just a day of the Test to go.

Nasser Hussain: It was one of the iconic days of Test cricket. That was magnificent watching. High quality fast bowling against one of the greatest batsmen there has ever been. There was a worry for a while about Smith but he came back like the champion he is.

Mike Atherton: An amazing spell of bowling and when Steve Smith was felled that added some trememdous drama from the day. Not that you ever want to see that happen.

Chris Woakes: We aren’t in the game to hurt people and we don’t wish anyone to be injured. It wasn’t nice to see but luckily it seems Steve is ok.

7.02pm BST

Rain stops play

Cummins delivers just two balls of the 33rd over, extremely wide of the crease before the clouds start to empty over Lord’s. England finish an eventful, gripping day with a lead of 104 and six wickets in hand. Bravo to Stokes and Buttler for curtailing their inner dragon in the final hour.

6.59pm BST

32nd over: England 96-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 16) Hazlewood, who has the look of thin, dark, Kiefer Sutherland replaces Lyon. He delivers a maiden.

And a couple of last emails on the Archer/Smith affair.

Damian Edgar is right that the world has changed since Lillee & Thommo writes Timothy Sanders. But expecting the emotional development of a young fast bowler to have changed with the times seems unfair. I never had a great sense of empathy when I was Archer’s age, nor indeed Buttler’s; and I didn’t have the awesome, scary ability that Archer has and Thommo had.

And Craig from Nottingham doesn’t think that any giggling/concern/non concern is the point.

It’s all well and good Australians putting a greater emphasis on apologising and asking whether a batter is ok after he’s been hit, but by that point the damage has already been done. The true callousness is in intentionally bowling short, fast deliveries in the first place; a far more sensible approach would be to discourage (or ban) bowlers from that kind of bowling. In that regard, Australia are no better than anyone else; Australia are very happy to still include those deliveries in their arsenal. Cummins and Hazlewood have consistently bowled short and fast to England on Thursday and again this afternoon (including to the tailenders, less equipped to protect themselves), with Burns, Denly, Woakes and others being hit. Plenty of those deliveries had the potential to cause serious injuries, regardless of any subsequent apologies or concern. While Archer could have shown more concern, concern doesn’t fix injuries.

6.51pm BST

31st over: England 96-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 16) Stokes plays and misses and fiddles his bat in frustration. His tattooed upper arms poke past his short sleeves - I bet it is painful being tattooed on the inside of the upper arm, like a baby’s bottom. Ah, now that’s something, Cummins strays off target and Stokes turns him down to the boundary.

6.47pm BST

30th over: England 90-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 10) Stokes is lucky to survive that over from Lyon, befuddled by two consecutive non-turning deliveries from Lyon.

6.45pm BST

29th over: England 89-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 9) A gripping micro-contest between bat and ball. An absolute corker from Cummins has Buttler desperately poking, then he clips Cummins away with some style, a quickstep shot with a top hat and cane.

6.40pm BST

28th over: England 83-4 (Buttler 8, Stokes 9) Lyon is sweet respite at the moment.

6.36pm BST

27th over: England 78-4 (Buttler 4, Stokes 8) England’s batting heroes of the World Cup final face off Cummins, pawing the ground at the top of his mark. They play out another maiden.

6.31pm BST

26th over: England 78-4 (Buttler 4, Stokes 8) Another Lyon maiden.

6.29pm BST

25th over: England 78-4 (Buttler 4, Stokes 8) As late afternoon sun settles over Lord’s, Stokes attempts thekind of shot you might buy in a joke shop - but escapes, somehow, unscathed.

And news - Steve Smith has not broken his arm and will be fit to bat tomorrow.

6.26pm BST

24th over: England 76-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 7)Sweet Lord, someone explain the review system to Australia again. They don’t review an lbw shout off Lyon once more, and a DRS replay shows Stokes, then on six, would have been heading back to the pavilion.

6.23pm BST

23rd over: England 75-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 6) A maiden from Siddle

Here’s my hot take for the OBO, writes Sebastian Lloyd - Buttler’s out of nick, replace him with Curran in the role of a batsman who can bowl a few overs. More reliable, more useful. Hopefully this means Jos gets a 60 ball hundred.

That is some jinx!

6.19pm BST

22nd over: England 75-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 6) Just a leg bye off the over, and a flurry of emails about Joe Denly, kind but questioning.

If only all the England batsmen followed Denly’s example and improved their Test average in both innings, they’d have no problems in this match, writes Geoff Wignall. On the other hand, after a single half century in 10 innings can/ should he be perservered with?

Dave Adams asks for perspective: Hope the selectors judge Denly’s contributions in context. Scores of 30 and 26 might be underwhelming, but they were the hardest of hard runs - helping England to partially rebuild in both innings.

6.15pm BST

21st over: England 74-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 6) Don’t forget we’ll be playing till seven tonight weather permitting... anyway, Buttler is off the mark with a tender shot through midwicket. Some rebuilding needed with some urgency. And we see Smith on the balcony, back from the hospital and somewhat dazed, but ok.

6.11pm BST

WICKET! Burns c Paine b Siddle 29

An absolute cracker from Siddle that rears and spits and Burns can’t take hjs bat away in time.

Updated at 7.13pm BST

6.09pm BST

20th over: England 64-3 (Burns 29, Stokes 6) With two left-handers at the crease, Paine whistles up for Lyon once again. And what an over he pulls out of the bag, having Stokes prodding and poking, until off the final ball Stokes goes forward and edges to first slip where Warner.... drops him.

Updated at 7.13pm BST

6.06pm BST

19th over: England 64-3 (Burns 28, Stokes 0) Stokes leapfrogs Buttler up the order and is rewarded by a leave-aloner from Siddle. Another bright start from Denly, but no cigar. The ball before he was out, he’d sent Siddle to the boundary with a most gorgeous whip through mid-wicket. But that was then.

6.02pm BST

WICKET! Denly caught and bowled Siddle 26

Aw shucks, Denly drives straight back to Siddle who with soft hands grabs the ball in the follow through.

5.59pm BST

18th over: England 56-2 (Burns 27, Denly 19) Hazlewood is back and Denly bears the brunt, fishing inelegantly at one that was wide enough for Moses to consider parting, before pulling one just short of deep square.

Lots more thoughtful emails, more than I can publish, for which apologies. First Damien Edgar from Victoria.

I would say that, from the perspective of most Australian cricket fans and (I would guess) players, our perspective on seeing players get hit, particularly around the head, fundamentally changed following the death of Phil Hughes. When I’m watching cricket now and someone gets hit on the head, it doesn’t matter who he plays for, I feel physically sick, and that feeling lingers beyond finding out that the player is OK. And I don’t think that I am alone in this. And because the death of Phil Hughes had such a massive impact on the Australian sporting psyche, I think that we imagined that it would have had a similar impact throughout the world.

There have been a few occasions since then when Australian fast bowlers have hit players on the head and they have immediately been at the player’s side to see if he is OK. From my perspective, it beggars belief that you would do anything different. Unless Archer was genuinely shaken and upset, in which case the appropriate response of his teammates is to actually see if he’s OK and put an arm around his shoulder and comfort him if he is not (or even if he says he is). It is not going over to him and sharing a joke and a giggle with him, while the opposing batsman is still being looked over by medical staff. And it is not clear that he was OK at this time – it can take hours and sometimes days for the side effects of head and brain injuries to present, let alone a couple of minutes. Bringing up Lillee and Thommo as some sort of rebuttal is callous and redundant – we no longer live in that world.

5.54pm BST

17th over: England 54-2 (Burns 26, Denly 18) Siddle drifts wide of leg stump and the ball flies past Paine and down for four byes. I hear a shout from the other room and City have gone one-up against Tottenham - which can’t be true otherwise the new footall season is happening at the same time as the second Ashes Test. That would be ridiculous. Denly edges Siddle through the slips for four and a look of intense irritation passes over Siddle’s face.

Stephen Davenport has an answer for Andrew Cosgrove’s musings on helmets.

..there is one way to protect that spot - get it out of the way of a bouncer. It’s a legitimate delivery, and I don’t recall any of this hue and cry when, for example, Malcolm Marshall was unapologetically picking bits of Mike Gatting’s nasal bone out of the ball. Then again, back then we didn’t have the raucous bear-pit that is Twitter.

5.48pm BST

16th over: England 46-2 (Burns 26, Denly 14) From the sublime to the ridiculous in two shots. First Joe Denly frolics down the pitch to lift Lyon over mid on for four glorious runs. Then he and Burns get in a right fix running between the wickets as Burns has his head in the clouds. Still, they’re still there, and that’s drinks.

5.44pm BST

15th over: England 41-2 (Burns 26, Denly 9) Summat simple from Peter Siddle.

5.40pm BST

14th over: England 39-2 (Burns 26, Denly 9) Rory Burns somehow survives an over from Nathan Lyon in which he would have been out lbw had Australia reviewed, and then plays a terrible slog-sweep that is heading for Neptune before falling back down but away from the Australian fielders. HE does manage a nice square cut too, to be fair.

5.35pm BST

13th over: England 30-2 (Burns 18, Denly 8) Denly is DROPPED by David Warner at first slip off Peter Siddle. He fends and Warner overbalances as he goes for the catch and the ball tips out of his fingertips. A lucky, lucky, lucky escape.

5.32pm BST

12th over: England 27-2 (Burns 18, Denly 6) Tim Pine goes for a double change, as Nathan Lyon replaces Hazlewood at the Nursery End. Burns, awkward, unconventional Burns, rouses the crowd with a boundary, a cut.

David Hinde has not time for sentiment or sacred cows. He’s straight to the point, and it is hardcore.

Hi Tanya. Hi David

So, can we now maybe confront the elephant in the room. “Joe Root is the only one of the big 4 not averaging over 50”. Err. There is no big 4. It’s a big 3. There have been and currently are countless batsmen whose career averages are higher than Root’s. But not one of them is english.


There are 2 issues here. The inability of an english batsman to sustain an average over 50. And the complete blindness of cricket journalists to the state of the averages of the latest hyped-up english batsman. This issue is ancient. It goes back 4 decades. But no one wants to discuss it. And if Moeen needs a break from all forms of cricket, what about Joe Root?

5.26pm BST

11th over: England 23-2 (Burns 13, Denly 6) Cummins is sent for a brief period of pasture and Siddle is summoned up for the cause. It’s a simple acceleration process - and a simple delivery stride, no angles, nothing tricksy. No great speed either, but he’s a master of his art, as anyone at Essex could testify. Anyway, he starts with a maiden.

5.22pm BST

10th over: England 23-2 (Burns 13, Denly 6) Denly gets hit in the guts at high speed by Hazlewood. We see his mouth open and his eyes screw up in slow motion. That hurt. He escapes the danger end by tucking the ball down to long leg, though respite is short as Burns takes a single off the next ball.

5.18pm BST

9th over: England 20-2 (Burns 12, Denly 4) Burns fiddles and twists - yes there are four slips behind you Rory. But he ducks a short one then knocks Cummins down to deep square leg for a couple more. At near parity with a just day to go, every run must have a value more than itself. R=r+3?

5.13pm BST

8th over: England 18-2 (Burns 10, Denly 4) Hazlewood,, ears signalling east and west as he runs in, keeping it tight, but Burns manages a run, a pull to deep square. It’ll be a full house tomorrow I wager. Cheap tickets for kids in the school holidays Lord’s?

5.09pm BST

7th over: England 17-2 (Burns 9, Denly 4) Cummins is bowling with fire here, but Burns and Denly survive. Denly even hits four, though without any conviction. Still, Gower has some kind words: “He’s got a good rhythm to him.”

What an interesting situation this match is in writes Andrew Cosgrove.
At tea, Sky was talking about how Smith wasn’t wearing a helmet with the new extra neck protection. But I don’t think that would have helped him, the ball looked like it hit him lower, and further forward. I don’t see how you can protect that spot without restricting head movement too much.

5.04pm BST

6th over: England 11-2 (Burns 7, Denly 0) Hazlewood has a plan for Burns. The plan is to bounce him. He nearly has his man, with an angry short ball that has Burns in a terrible tangle, arms up by his ears, chest facing the bowler.

4.59pm BST

5th over: England 9-2 (Burns 7, Denly 0) Who would you choose to face a hat-trick ball from Pat Cummins? Joe Denly is the man at the top of your pack. He survives, hit high, too high, on the pad. Cummins finishes the over by running through him. What an over. England look like a boiled egg with cracks.

4.54pm BST

Wicket! Root c Paine by Cummins 0

A golden duck for Joe Root. He prods at the ball and feathers behind to Paine. Cummins is on a hat-trick...

Updated at 5.02pm BST

4.52pm BST

WICKET! Roy caught and bowled Cummins

A leading edge from a bouncer, that squares Roy up, sends the ball high and is well caught by Cummins running backwards. One thing - I think the hands were ok.

Updated at 5.03pm BST

4.49pm BST

4th over: England 9-0 (Burns 7, Roy 2) Jason - no! Those HARD HANDS push forward at Hazlewood and the ball falls a foot or so short of second slip. A nudge off the hip takes him out of the danger end.

Plenty more emails on Archer/Smith:

Simon Horbury has dug out a quote from the 1970s

Dear Tanya

You might like this quote from a fast bowler:

“I enjoy hitting a batsman more than getting him out. I like to see blood on the pitch.”

Some bloke call Jeff Thomson...think he played for Engl...oops Aussie wasn’t he?

4.45pm BST

3rd over: England 8-0 (Burns 7, Roy 1) Roy is watchful, careful, all the fuls just making sure he’s not in any way reck ful less. 12.37pm BST

58th over: Australia 135-5 (Smith 35, Paine 20) “Go on Leachy,” says YJB from behind the stumps. “Wobble a few down there!” Yep, it’s SPIN for the first time in this innings, replacing Woakes with 28 minutes remaining in the session. Paine plays each ball watchfully.

“To spare Jamie H’s wife’s woes in learning a new cricketing-related lingo (51st over), tell him radio 4 LW reaches far far far into France, and his car should pick it up,” notes Luke Brown, helpfully! “I’ve tested it down to beyond the Burgundy Hills (four hours south of Paris, is the max, I’d say), on the way to the Alps. Fair wind etc.
However, i myself am stranded (LW-wise) in Hungary, so keep the OBO coming to combat the heavy-food-and-scorching-sun afternoon-lethargy.”

Great to have your company. Stick with us all day long.

“PS - I told my infant son about the vital need for Steve Smith to be got out. He looked into my eyes, yawned, and fell asleep. I see a future for him in the pavilion.”

Get him on that waiting list, now! We’re having a baby in February (I don’t think I told you guys that? Exciting, innit?!) and the first thing I’m doing when they are born: both MCC lists and Adelaide Oval.

12.33pm BST

57th over: Australia 135-5 (Smith 35, Paine 20) The last over of Archer’s morning, perhaps? Nothing wrong with it, leaping one back at Paine’s thigh pad along the way, but both the captain then Smith are able to keep him out. The best delivery is, once again, saved for last: a full off-cutter that Smith gets down on in the nick of time.

12.31pm BST

56th over: Australia 134-5 (Smith 35, Paine 20) Useful runs, aren’t they all? Buzzzzers when Stokes takes a ping at the non-strikers’ stumps, wide enough that Paine gets a couple of bonus runs. Building in confidence, the captain was also able to put away a rare poor ball from Woakes, slamming it through cover off the back foot.

“Why is Jack Leach in the team?” asks Aditya Kohli. I suspect he is going to be into the attack very soon. Has a major role against Smith.

Love this. Mel Jones - one of the truly great cricket people. After making her maiden Ashes ton in 1998, she did the clinic circuit when returning home. Remember well her schooling us on her vicious cut shot. In short: to hell with rolling your wrists when making contact, hit down on the ball to begin and it doesn’t matter.

Updated at 12.36pm BST

12.25pm BST

55th over: Australia 127-5 (Smith 35, Paine 13) Paine is battling but that’s what is required of him here. As Justin Langer said before the Test, they want to get bulk overs into Archer and see how effective he might be when tired. In order to do that, players like Paine need to soak up overs like this. There’s a ripper to finish - isn’t there always when Archer is involved? - leaping up at his handle, the captain nursing it down to the gully on the bounce. Well played.

“Why aren’t England bowling round the wicket to Smith, aiming yorkers at leg stump with a 3-6 field?” asks Brian Withington. “It might not get him out but surely it has to disrupt his perennial method of moving across to off?”

I think it has to do with the fact that they tried a lot of unorthodox plans last week and turned too them far too early in Smith’s innings, especially the second time around. Root said before this Test that they were going to go at him as long as they could with conventional measures. It feels like it has been working relatively well so far?

12.21pm BST

54th over: Australia 126-5 (Smith 35, Paine 12) Woakes is fuller to Paine, jagging back at him this time to find the inside edge! Close. And he does it again to finish! He’s the man most likely right now.

“I‘ll see your Keith Arthurton and raise you a Carl Hooper,” says Hary Naylor. “Nobody hit sixes more smoothly than Super Hoops.”

The answer to a top quiz question as well. I’ll get this wrong, but it goes something like... Hooper is the only man (other than Kallis?) to have played 100 Tests, 100 ODIs, taken 100 catches in both formats, snagged 100 wickets in both formats. Anyway, it’s a good’un when asked properly. And yes, boy, could he give the ball a wallop.

12.16pm BST

53th over: Australia 121-5 (Smith 34, Paine 8) Smith edges Archer’s... slower ball? 76mph flashes up after the ball trickes into the cordon, deflected there with soft enough hands. He can put his bat away for the middle portion of the over, leaving and swaying, but misses a beauty to finish, so close to cutting him in half, jagging past his inside edge. Two busy overs since the drinks break.

Updated at 1.37pm BST

12.13pm BST

52nd over: Australia 121-5 (Smith 34, Paine 8) Woakes beats Smith with a good’un. That’s why he takes so many wickets on this ground - gorgrous shape. Ooh, he goes the other way to Paine - a big shout for leg before... turned down. No review; going over the top. He the beats Paine with another outswinger to finish the excellent set.

“To broaden the smoothness debate from bowling to batting: a mate of mine once found himself bowling to Keith Arthurton in a charity match,” recalls Boris Starling. “His first ball was on a length outside off. Arthurton nonchalantly leaned into the cover drive and purred the single word ‘smoooothness’ as the ball sped to the boundary.”

Oh yes, a name from my childhood there. Yes, Australian fans feared all the usual suspects in that West Indian line-up but Arthurton was as classy as any of them at his 1992-93 peak.

12.06pm BST

51st over: Australia 120-5 (Smith 33, Paine 8) Archer is swung around to the pavilion end, as he was yesterday for that fierce spell at Bancroft. He doesn’t take long to make the ball talk, four byes added when a ball goes down the slope and deviates too far from Bairstow to glove. For the second time since his arrival, Paine tries to pull the big quick but ends up in a tangle. Might put that shot away for now, skip. Smith pushes a single to keep the strike. DRINKS! If only we had two days after this and not one, this Test would be perfectly positioned. But there’s still enough time - just.

“Long time listener, first time caller.” We love those, Jamie Hudson. Welcome. “Long drive home today through France. Enjoying the coverage. Long suffering wife reading out updates while I drive (also typing this). She describes it as similar to trying to read aloud in an unfamiliar foreign language- difficult to know where to put the emphasis when you don’t know what the sentences mean!”

12.00pm BST

50th over: Australia 114-5 (Smith 32, Paine 7) The Lord’s Specialist, Chris Woakes, on to replace Archer from his preferred Nursery End. He picked up Khawaja yesterday at an important time, the second wicket in the space of three balls. Smith missed out on a flick through the onside, much to his frustration. He does get one to mid-on, Paine then glancing a single before the former captain finishes with two behind point along the carpet. He’s into the 30s and has faced 75 balls. His average when reaching 50 deliveries in the middle is 100-plus, I’m sorry to report to those desperate to see his back.

11.55am BST

49th over: Australia 110-5 (Smith 29, Paine 6) The sun is back. It’s that kind of morning; light and shade. Broad hoops an inswinging yorker at Smith, nearly castling him. He gets his bat down at the last possible moment. So cose. Paine then gets a couple through point from another delivery aimed in towards the stumps. Great spell, this.


11.51am BST

48th over: Australia 107-5 (Smith 28, Paine 4) Smith pushes Archer to mid-on to begin, putting Paine in the firing line for the first time at this end. The skipper tries to pull but isn’t quick enough, edging into his pad - where is the short leg? Not there. But he keeps his cool, deflecting the next with soft hands well behind point for four to get off the mark. Australia are still 151 behind, it is worth remembering.

11.48am BST

47th over: Australia 102-5 (Smith 27, Paine 0) Broad at the fresh man Paine, the captain having to defend on the line of his off stump four times before he’s given the chance to shoulder arms. Full and straight, Broad isn’t mucking around. Three maidens on the trot.

11.44am BST

46th over: Australia 102-5 (Smith 27, Paine 0) It is dark again at Lord’s, the lights on full with Archer starting his fresh set. As I noted before, credit his way as well for Wade’s wicket, hitting him twice in his two previous overs. At Smith this time, he goes well beyond his outside edge playing off the back foot. Dangerous areas. Smith then has a pop at one that he would normally leave well alone, the bowler again winning the mini-battle. This is good stuff. The bouncer to finish is followed by Smith’s eyes all the way into Bairstow’s gloves, prompting more giggles. Find a telly, this is great entertainment.

Updated at 12.10pm BST

11.39am BST

45th over: Australia 102-5 (Smith 27, Paine 0) Broad has been rewarded for bowling such a full length - as Nasser Hussain notes on telly, fuller than at any stage in his career. As someone clever noted in the press box last week, professional athletes usually have to improve quite a lot at Broad’s age to stay relevant and that’s precisely what he’s done ahead of this summer. Paine is the new man, getting a nasty one to begin that jumps at his handle, the captain ripping his hand off the bat. He hates those, given the number of finger operations he’s required. Wicket maiden.




11.34am BST

WICKET! Wade c Burns b Broad 6 (Australia 102-5)

Fantastic bowling! Broad brings Wade forward from around the wicket, tailing away from the left-hander. He finds the edge, just carrying to Burns at third slip. An excellent low catch. Wade, who looked so good before Archer roughed him up, is on his way.

Updated at 1.35pm BST

11.32am BST

44th over: Australia 102-4 (Smith 27, Wade 6) Ouch, Archer hits Wade again this time - this time on the shoulder. Smith dealt with him easily enough before taking one to mid-on, watching carefully.

11.31am BST

43rd over: Australia 100-4 (Smith 26, Wade 6) Smith is making a habit of scoring behind square early in the over, helping Broad in that direction for Australia’s 100th run. Warm applause from the packed Lord’s crowd - they love their Saturdays at HQ. Wade is forced to use his bat in defence until the final ball, Broad from around the wicket hooping back a long way; not far from that off-stump with the No6 shouldering arms. Top notch cricket so far.

“Sat in Jakarta airport after a combined 16 hours in transit,” Harry Coleman reports to me on twitter. “Can’t speak to much really but how about that The Shape of Water, hey? My vote for smoothest action goes to the big charming fish man.”

Slept in the bath, you say, Smithy? Norwegian Wood, then.



11.25am BST

42nd over: Australia 99-4 (Smith 25, Wade 6) Archer it is, replacing Stokes after just a couple of overs. He’s full to Smith immediately, clipping one to fine leg. Wade has to be right on it, under an accurate bumper then directing into his body at 90mph. He’s good enough to keep him out. Ooh, the last ball is a nasty one, hitting Wade on the fingers. He takes his glove off between overs to give his hand a shake. He hasn’t called for the medical staff, so that’s a good sign.

11.21am BST

41st over: Australia 98-4 (Smith 24, Wade 6) Broad and Smith are both in the game here; a fantastic contest emerging early on this fourth day. To begin, the Australian hammers him through cover off the back foot for the second time so far - there wasn’t much wrong with that ball, either. The England attack-leader bounces back with the second delivery of the morning that’s good enough to beat Smith. A beauty, seaming up the slope. When Wade gets his turn, he drives a full delivery with lovely timing, beating mid-off. With it, the Tasmanian reaches 1000 Test Match runs. Nine off the over.

“If Jardine were in charge he would place two very short legs in place (perhaps Stokes and Woakes) and thereby prevent Smith doing his waddle out to short leg,” suggests Will Buckley. “Get in his head, muck up his OCD routine and watch his mind unravel.”

Updated at 2.03pm BST

11.14am BST

40th over: Australia 89-4 (Smith 19, Wade 2) Probing over from Stokes, well watched initially by Wade who is later able to dig out a yorker down for one. Smith is happy enough jumping across his woodwork for another single to finish, tucking to fine leg.

“Morning Adam.” G’day, Kim Thonger. “Sorry to start the day in disagreement but on the question of smoothness, everyone else is wrong. Tom Cartwright had by far the smoothest action and only missed out on more Test cricket because of moronic selection policy. Not a recent development obvs.”

How about Jofra bowling 94mph bumpers yesterday? Doesn’t the radar slow most bowlers down when they dig in short? More! More!

11.10am BST

39th over: Australia 87-4 (Smith 18, Wade 1) Smith beaten! Broad goes past his blade with his first ball of the morning - dare I say, a nervous prod? Sure enough, the former captain is furious at himself and shifts into light-sabre mode as the sun comes out from behind the clouds. What a glorious sight. Just on Smith’s odd habits when leaving the ball, he doesn’t do it all the time. As he’s explained when I’ve asked him about it before, this is a clue that he’s trying to shift into his highest level of concentration. With a bit of width, he pushes a boundary with ease through point off the back foot; so much time, lovely batting. He then defends the final ball and kicks his legs up like he’s setting up to take a diving catch - the crowd laugh as one. “Surplus energy,” says Ian Botham. Something like that.

11.04am BST

38th over: Australia 82-4 (Smith 14, Wade 1) Ahh, that’s right: Ben Stokes had five balls remaining when the rain arrived two minutes before the lunch break yesterday. The first of those is to Wade, who clips one to get off the mark from the 24th ball he has faced. The Tasmanian did very nicely in tough conditions yesterday, reinforcing that his technique is a lot tighter than during his previous stints as a Test player. Smith’s turn and Stokes gets one to spit off a length, the Aussie master forced to rip his bottom hand off the blade. It doesn’t bother him too much though, getting his first run of the day from the next delivery, tucked neatly behind square. Good morning to you all!

11.00am BST

Thanks, JP! The players are on the field, Ben Stokes to begin from in front of my position at the Nursery End. Wade is the man on strike. We have 196 overs remaining in this Test Match. Bring it on. PLAY!

Updated at 11.00am BST

10.58am BST

Right, the players are making their way out to the middle so it’s time for me to stand aside and let Collo have an uninterrupted view of the middle. Thanks for having me, see you again tomorrow.

10.57am BST

We’re now just five minutes from the resumption of play. That means you should start sending your emails and tweets Adam Collins’s way because I will soon be off to put my feet up.

10.55am BST

Yes please!

10.53am BST

Andersonwatch update:

10.52am BST

“Richard Hadlee was the smoothest of all, surely,” emails Mike Herd, “with a word for Mike Hendrick too.”

10.50am BST

Just ten minutes or so until play resumes. Can England dismiss Smith cheaply and send a shockwave through the Australian dressing room?

10.46am BST

Here we go, Bharathan knows his Onions.

10.44am BST

Raymond Reardon (not that one), has turned up with the lols. “Smith, Warner and Bancroft would be the three smoothest woodworkers for using a fine 180 grit.”

10.43am BST

Thomas Hopkins likes a bit of rough. “I may be swimming against the tide here, but I rather enjoy a lack of smoothness, Jasprit Bumrah a current favourite player. There’s something delightfully contrary about his action.”

10.42am BST

10.41am BST

When we talk smooth bowling actions we’re naturally drawn to pace, but what about SK Warne? Has there been a more fluid action in the game?

10.39am BST

Steve Smith doing Steve Smith things...

10.38am BST

Because we change writers during the day we will often receive emails intended for the person on deck long after we’ve logged off. Sometimes these provide obvious clues about what was being discussed in our absence, like Scott Roberts’s email titled “Getting Smith out”. (His answer, by the way, is “decide how we’re trying to get Smith out and stick to that plan”.) But on other occasions it is frankly impossible to imagine what on earth was going on. This morning, for example, I logged on to find an email from David Baker with the message “The Communards, Don’t leave me this way.” No idea what it was related to, but it’s a banger.

10.36am BST

A lovely interjection from Mr Naylor.

Agree with a lot of this. Here’s an Allan Donald masterclass.

10.34am BST

Frantic yet smooth makes me think of the scene in 24 Hour Party People where Martin Hannett wants Joy Division to play “faster but slower”. Caddick was a beauty though. Very repeatable and consistent, but smoother than Archer?

10.29am BST

If there’s cricket news about Ali Martin will sniff it out. Like confirmation Olly Stone will miss the rest of the Ashes through injury.

Related: Fresh blow to England as Olly Stone is ruled out for rest of series

10.29am BST

Overseas? Want to listen to TMS but can’t find it on your dial? Try this link, courtesy of Peter Crees.

10.25am BST

“I put forward Shane Bond in the smooth action category,” nominates Avitaj Mitra. “A pity his career was wrecked with injuries. The stats don’t do justice to the kind of bowler he was.” Superb bowler, but for me anyway not in the same class as someone like Holding for smoothness. Bond’s action is all about the effort in the snap of the delivery stride.

10.21am BST

Curtley’s a nice shout. I used to love how his smooth action concealed a Pythagorean use of angles.

10.18am BST

Here’s your day four deck. Will it prove treacherous enough to snare ten Englishmen or 16 Australians in the next two days?

10.16am BST

John Starbuck is quickest off the mark in the daily email race. Attracted to the blog by the lure of smooth. “Michael Holding, Malcolm Marshall and Richard Hadlee are top of my list,” John emails. “We shall have to wait a season or two before Jofra Archer finds his correct place in the Dean Martin Stakes.” Three superb bowlers, each with very different actions. For pure smooth though I’m leaning towards Holding.

10.08am BST

Andy Bull had the pleasure of filing his column on Jofra Archer. Question: where does Archer’s action rank on the all-time smoothness scale? We can have subcategories for contemporary and all-time comparison.

Related: Jofra Archer quickly becomes England’s go-to bowler for all occasions | Andy Bull

10.03am BST

Weather: The headline news is the forecast is dry for the remainder of the Test. Aside from that it should be around 20C for most of today but there’s a stiff south-westerly which should keep everyone in Lord’s on their toes.

9.54am BST

Already forgotten what happened yesterday? Fear not because Vic Marks didn’t miss a thing. This paragraph in particular captures the state of play.

That outcome is still by no means guaranteed, however, and the captains will ensure none of the players is seduced into concluding the draw is inevitable – and with good reason. In the 21st century batsmen are less adept at batting out for a draw and there are still 196 overs available in the second Ashes Test.

Related: Jofra Archer off mark for England but threat of second Test draw looms

9.51am BST

That’ll do.

9.36am BST

Preamble

Hello everybody and welcome to the fourth day of the second Test from Lord’s.

The good news is the rain has cleared and we’re set for a full day’s play. The bad news is, frankly, all over the place right now so let’s not dwell on that half of the aphorism and just enjoy the cricket, like this 24 carat nugget of pure joy.

If that didn’t make you smile you’ve got a brick for a heart and we can’t be friends.

I’ll be with you for the next hour or so but once play begins Adam Collins will shower you in text. If you want to join in this pre-play fun you can drop me an email or a tweet.
fields.bodyText: Time to call it a day here, after some of the most gripping sessions of Test cricket I can remember. That Archer to Smith spell, high speed and guile against an outstanding batsman with daemons in his head, will be imprinted on many minds this evening The horrendous felling of Smith was awful to watch, and thankfully he’s ok. And yet, it may have torn a hole in his protective cocoon that has worked hitherto so well this series. We must watch and wait. And after all that, England’s batsmen batted through a torrid last session. Of course, it could all end in a draw - but don’t miss a ball tomorrow. Phew - time for a stretch. Have a great evening everyone! And while I remember, thank you so much for all your emails and sorry I couldn’t print them all. One more to finish on, from Matt Redgrave, a thoughtful reply to Damien Edgar’s similarly sensitive mail. Think its all pretty valid. The Phil Hughes death hasn’t changed the culture over here and we tend not to have high speed bowlers and fast wickets that often, so it is understandable that English cricket hasnt done this thinking. Time to do it now though..Also Archer was 19 when Hughes tragically died. Root as captain should guide him. I’d expect a captain to head over to the Aussie camp and check he’s ok and express concern. “It was a terrible blow and it looked horrible at the time but thankfully Steve is ok, “ says Justin Langer. Ian Ward asks whether Smith was ok to come out after his wild slog for four in the eighties and then his change of mind about the review when he was out. Langer reassures us that Smith was fine. HE then goes on to explain that Smith is one of the few players who doesn’t wear a stem guard on his helmet - his personal choice, he can’t feel comfortable with it. I don’t really know where to start with today. Two sides going at each other with everything, divided by a piece of RICE paper, with just a day of the Test to go. Nasser Hussain: It was one of the iconic days of Test cricket. That was magnificent watching. High quality fast bowling against one of the greatest batsmen there has ever been. There was a worry for a while about Smith but he came back like the champion he is. Mike Atherton: An amazing spell of bowling and when Steve Smith was felled that added some trememdous drama from the day. Not that you ever want to see that happen. Chris Woakes: We aren’t in the game to hurt people and we don’t wish anyone to be injured. It wasn’t nice to see but luckily it seems Steve is ok. Cummins delivers just two balls of the 33rd over, extremely wide of the crease before the clouds start to empty over Lord’s. England finish an eventful, gripping day with a lead of 104 and six wickets in hand. Bravo to Stokes and Buttler for curtailing their inner dragon in the final hour. 32nd over: England 96-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 16) Hazlewood, who has the look of thin, dark, Kiefer Sutherland replaces Lyon. He delivers a maiden. And a couple of last emails on the Archer/Smith affair. Damian Edgar is right that the world has changed since Lillee & Thommo writes Timothy Sanders. But expecting the emotional development of a young fast bowler to have changed with the times seems unfair. I never had a great sense of empathy when I was Archer’s age, nor indeed Buttler’s; and I didn’t have the awesome, scary ability that Archer has and Thommo had. And Craig from Nottingham doesn’t think that any giggling/concern/non concern is the point. It’s all well and good Australians putting a greater emphasis on apologising and asking whether a batter is ok after he’s been hit, but by that point the damage has already been done. The true callousness is in intentionally bowling short, fast deliveries in the first place; a far more sensible approach would be to discourage (or ban) bowlers from that kind of bowling. In that regard, Australia are no better than anyone else; Australia are very happy to still include those deliveries in their arsenal. Cummins and Hazlewood have consistently bowled short and fast to England on Thursday and again this afternoon (including to the tailenders, less equipped to protect themselves), with Burns, Denly, Woakes and others being hit. Plenty of those deliveries had the potential to cause serious injuries, regardless of any subsequent apologies or concern. While Archer could have shown more concern, concern doesn’t fix injuries. 31st over: England 96-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 16) Stokes plays and misses and fiddles his bat in frustration. His tattooed upper arms poke past his short sleeves - I bet it is painful being tattooed on the inside of the upper arm, like a baby’s bottom. Ah, now that’s something, Cummins strays off target and Stokes turns him down to the boundary. 30th over: England 90-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 10) Stokes is lucky to survive that over from Lyon, befuddled by two consecutive non-turning deliveries from Lyon. 29th over: England 89-4 (Buttler 10, Stokes 9) A gripping micro-contest between bat and ball. An absolute corker from Cummins has Buttler desperately poking, then he clips Cummins away with some style, a quickstep shot with a top hat and cane. 28th over: England 83-4 (Buttler 8, Stokes 9) Lyon is sweet respite at the moment. 27th over: England 78-4 (Buttler 4, Stokes 8) England’s batting heroes of the World Cup final face off Cummins, pawing the ground at the top of his mark. They play out another maiden. 26th over: England 78-4 (Buttler 4, Stokes 8) Another Lyon maiden. 25th over: England 78-4 (Buttler 4, Stokes 8) As late afternoon sun settles over Lord’s, Stokes attempts thekind of shot you might buy in a joke shop - but escapes, somehow, unscathed. And news - Steve Smith has not broken his arm and will be fit to bat tomorrow. 24th over: England 76-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 7)Sweet Lord, someone explain the review system to Australia again. They don’t review an lbw shout off Lyon once more, and a DRS replay shows Stokes, then on six, would have been heading back to the pavilion. 23rd over: England 75-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 6) A maiden from Siddle Here’s my hot take for the OBO, writes Sebastian Lloyd - Buttler’s out of nick, replace him with Curran in the role of a batsman who can bowl a few overs. More reliable, more useful. Hopefully this means Jos gets a 60 ball hundred. That is some jinx! 22nd over: England 75-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 6) Just a leg bye off the over, and a flurry of emails about Joe Denly, kind but questioning. If only all the England batsmen followed Denly’s example and improved their Test average in both innings, they’d have no problems in this match, writes Geoff Wignall. On the other hand, after a single half century in 10 innings can/ should he be perservered with? Dave Adams asks for perspective: Hope the selectors judge Denly’s contributions in context. Scores of 30 and 26 might be underwhelming, but they were the hardest of hard runs - helping England to partially rebuild in both innings. 21st over: England 74-4 (Buttler 3, Stokes 6) Don’t forget we’ll be playing till seven tonight weather permitting... anyway, Buttler is off the mark with a tender shot through midwicket. Some rebuilding needed with some urgency. And we see Smith on the balcony, back from the hospital and somewhat dazed, but ok. An absolute cracker from Siddle that rears and spits and Burns can’t take hjs bat away in time. 20th over: England 64-3 (Burns 29, Stokes 6) With two left-handers at the crease, Paine whistles up for Lyon once again. And what an over he pulls out of the bag, having Stokes prodding and poking, until off the final ball Stokes goes forward and edges to first slip where Warner.... drops him. 19th over: England 64-3 (Burns 28, Stokes 0) Stokes leapfrogs Buttler up the order and is rewarded by a leave-aloner from Siddle. Another bright start from Denly, but no cigar. The ball before he was out, he’d sent Siddle to the boundary with a most gorgeous whip through mid-wicket. But that was then. Aw shucks, Denly drives straight back to Siddle who with soft hands grabs the ball in the follow through. 18th over: England 56-2 (Burns 27, Denly 19) Hazlewood is back and Denly bears the brunt, fishing inelegantly at one that was wide enough for Moses to consider parting, before pulling one just short of deep square. Lots more thoughtful emails, more than I can publish, for which apologies. First Damien Edgar from Victoria. I would say that, from the perspective of most Australian cricket fans and (I would guess) players, our perspective on seeing players get hit, particularly around the head, fundamentally changed following the death of Phil Hughes. When I’m watching cricket now and someone gets hit on the head, it doesn’t matter who he plays for, I feel physically sick, and that feeling lingers beyond finding out that the player is OK. And I don’t think that I am alone in this. And because the death of Phil Hughes had such a massive impact on the Australian sporting psyche, I think that we imagined that it would have had a similar impact throughout the world. There have been a few occasions since then when Australian fast bowlers have hit players on the head and they have immediately been at the player’s side to see if he is OK. From my perspective, it beggars belief that you would do anything different. Unless Archer was genuinely shaken and upset, in which case the appropriate response of his teammates is to actually see if he’s OK and put an arm around his shoulder and comfort him if he is not (or even if he says he is). It is not going over to him and sharing a joke and a giggle with him, while the opposing batsman is still being looked over by medical staff. And it is not clear that he was OK at this time – it can take hours and sometimes days for the side effects of head and brain injuries to present, let alone a couple of minutes. Bringing up Lillee and Thommo as some sort of rebuttal is callous and redundant – we no longer live in that world. 17th over: England 54-2 (Burns 26, Denly 18) Siddle drifts wide of leg stump and the ball flies past Paine and down for four byes. I hear a shout from the other room and City have gone one-up against Tottenham - which can’t be true otherwise the new footall season is happening at the same time as the second Ashes Test. That would be ridiculous. Denly edges Siddle through the slips for four and a look of intense irritation passes over Siddle’s face. Stephen Davenport has an answer for Andrew Cosgrove’s musings on helmets. ..there is one way to protect that spot - get it out of the way of a bouncer. Martin Gillam has a smoothness suggestion before lunch too: “One idiosyncratic category would be smoothness of hitting - has anyone hit more effortless, sweetly timed sixes than your (near) namesake, Adam Gilchrist?” No complaints here. Truly changed the game. Speaking of the footy/cricket link... 61st over: Australia 148-5 (Smith 48, Paine 20) So good from Smith, this time staying at home rather than jumping over the stumps; he knew that’s where and when Stokes’ full ball was coming. Don’t doubt his telepathic skills. In turn, he’s able to hammer it down the ground for four. Paine misses a pull shot later in the over, the third time this morning, and there is appeal as it has kept a lot lower than he thought. It’s turned down and there’s no review. Variable bounce? “Smooth batsmen (that sounded weird in my head),” writes Avitaj Mitra. “I nominate Damien Martyn. Made it seem so effortless all the time. Lazy elegance is the term, I believe.” Yep. Easy on the eye. And, for a while there in 2016, one of only 40-odd people in the world that Donald Trump followed on Twitter. No kidding. My dear colleague Charlie Reynolds wrote the yarn. 60th over: Australia 141-5 (Smith 41, Paine 20) Bad from Broad, Smith getting off strike - with three runs - when the big quick lets a ball through his legs at backward point. It’ll be doubly frustrating for Root as the delivery before it did beat Smith’s inside edge. That’s the part of the bat the spinner locates when Paine is at the business end but there are no catchers in close. There really should be a couple of those for Leach early in this spell. Wickets matter, not runs, in this rain-reduced game. Give the bloke every opportunity. Lovely over. 59th over: Australia 138-5 (Smith 38, Paine 20) I was right about it being Archer’s last over for now - thanks for listening, Joe. Stokes is back for a pre-lunch blast. I don’t mind that. There should be a bit of reverse there for him. Oooh, he does get one to move back at Smith. Of course, he is good enough to whip it away for two but that is worth having another pop at when Paine is on strike. The bumper follows then the one that spits at Smith’s gloves. He gets that bottom hand right off the blade, expertly. “Nothing worries him,” says Sangakkara on telly. Stokes has a stare. Short of a length again to finish, Smith jumps over to grab one and keep the strike. So, Leach will get a chance at Smith for the first time. An important period. 58th over: Australia 135-5 (Smith 35, Paine 20) “Go on Leachy,” says YJB from behind the stumps. “Wobble a few down there!” Yep, it’s SPIN for the first time in this innings, replacing Woakes with 28 minutes remaining in the session. Paine plays each ball watchfully. “To spare Jamie H’s wife’s woes in learning a new cricketing-related lingo (51st over), tell him radio 4 LW reaches far far far into France, and his car should pick it up,” notes Luke Brown, helpfully! “I’ve tested it down to beyond the Burgundy Hills (four hours south of Paris, is the max, I’d say), on the way to the Alps. Fair wind etc. However, i myself am stranded (LW-wise) in Hungary, so keep the OBO coming to combat the heavy-food-and-scorching-sun afternoon-lethargy.” Great to have your company. Stick with us all day long. “PS - I told my infant son about the vital need for Steve Smith to be got out. He looked into my eyes, yawned, and fell asleep. I see a future for him in the pavilion.” Get him on that waiting list, now! We’re having a baby in February (I don’t think I told you guys that? Exciting, innit?!) and the first thing I’m doing when they are born: both MCC lists and Adelaide Oval. 57th over: Australia 135-5 (Smith 35, Paine 20) The last over of Archer’s morning, perhaps? Nothing wrong with it, leaping one back at Paine’s thigh pad along the way, but both the captain then Smith are able to keep him out. The best delivery is, once again, saved for last: a full off-cutter that Smith gets down on in the nick of time. 56th over: Australia 134-5 (Smith 35, Paine 20) Useful runs, aren’t they all? Buzzzzers when Stokes takes a ping at the non-strikers’ stumps, wide enough that Paine gets a couple of bonus runs. Building in confidence, the captain was also able to put away a rare poor ball from Woakes, slamming it through cover off the back foot. “Why is Jack Leach in the team?” asks Aditya Kohli. I suspect he is going to be into the attack very soon. Has a major role against Smith. Love this. Mel Jones - one of the truly great cricket people. After making her maiden Ashes ton in 1998, she did the clinic circuit when returning home. Remember well her schooling us on her vicious cut shot. In short: to hell with rolling your wrists when making contact, hit down on the ball to begin and it doesn’t matter. 55th over: Australia 127-5 (Smith 35, Paine 13) Paine is battling but that’s what is required of him here. As Justin Langer said before the Test, they want to get bulk overs into Archer and see how effective he might be when tired. In order to do that, players like Paine need to soak up overs like this. There’s a ripper to finish - isn’t there always when Archer is involved? - leaping up at his handle, the captain nursing it down to the gully on the bounce. Well played. “Why aren’t England bowling round the wicket to Smith, aiming yorkers at leg stump with a 3-6 field?” asks Brian Withington. “It might not get him out but surely it has to disrupt his perennial method of moving across to off?” I think it has to do with the fact that they tried a lot of unorthodox plans last week and turned too them far too early in Smith’s innings, especially the second time around. Root said before this Test that they were going to go at him as long as they could with conventional measures. It feels like it has been working relatively well so far? 54th over: Australia 126-5 (Smith 35, Paine 12) Woakes is fuller to Paine, jagging back at him this time to find the inside edge! Close. And he does it again to finish! He’s the man most likely right now. “I‘ll see your Keith Arthurton and raise you a Carl Hooper,” says Hary Naylor. “Nobody hit sixes more smoothly than Super Hoops.” The answer to a top quiz question as well. I’ll get this wrong, but it goes something like... Hooper is the only man (other than Kallis?) to have played 100 Tests, 100 ODIs, taken 100 catches in both formats, snagged 100 wickets in both formats. Anyway, it’s a good’un when asked properly. And yes, boy, could he give the ball a wallop. 53th over: Australia 121-5 (Smith 34, Paine 8) Smith edges Archer’s... slower ball? 76mph flashes up after the ball trickes into the cordon, deflected there with soft enough hands. He can put his bat away for the middle portion of the over, leaving and swaying, but misses a beauty to finish, so close to cutting him in half, jagging past his inside edge. Two busy overs since the drinks break. 52nd over: Australia 121-5 (Smith 34, Paine 8) Woakes beats Smith with a good’un. That’s why he takes so many wickets on this ground - gorgrous shape. Ooh, he goes the other way to Paine - a big shout for leg before... turned down. No review; going over the top. He the beats Paine with another outswinger to finish the excellent set. “To broaden the smoothness debate from bowling to batting: a mate of mine once found himself bowling to Keith Arthurton in a charity match,” recalls Boris Starling. “His first ball was on a length outside off. Arthurton nonchalantly leaned into the cover drive and purred the single word ‘smoooothness’ as the ball sped to the boundary.” Oh yes, a name from my childhood there. Yes, Australian fans feared all the usual suspects in that West Indian line-up but Arthurton was as classy as any of them at his 1992-93 peak. 51st over: Australia 120-5 (Smith 33, Paine 8) Archer is swung around to the pavilion end, as he was yesterday for that fierce spell at Bancroft. He doesn’t take long to make the ball talk, four byes added when a ball goes down the slope and deviates too far from Bairstow to glove. For the second time since his arrival, Paine tries to pull the big quick but ends up in a tangle. Might put that shot away for now, skip. Smith pushes a single to keep the strike. DRINKS! If only we had two days after this and not one, this Test would be perfectly positioned. But there’s still enough time - just. “Long time listener, first time caller.” We love those, Jamie Hudson. Welcome. “Long drive home today through France. Enjoying the coverage. Long suffering wife reading out updates while I drive (also typing this). She describes it as similar to trying to read aloud in an unfamiliar foreign language- difficult to know where to put the emphasis when you don’t know what the sentences mean!” 50th over: Australia 114-5 (Smith 32, Paine 7) The Lord’s Specialist, Chris Woakes, on to replace Archer from his preferred Nursery End. He picked up Khawaja yesterday at an important time, the second wicket in the space of three balls. Smith missed out on a flick through the onside, much to his frustration. He does get one to mid-on, Paine then glancing a single before the former captain finishes with two behind point along the carpet. He’s into the 30s and has faced 75 balls. His average when reaching 50 deliveries in the middle is 100-plus, I’m sorry to report to those desperate to see his back. 49th over: Australia 110-5 (Smith 29, Paine 6) The sun is back. It’s that kind of morning; light and shade. Broad hoops an inswinging yorker at Smith, nearly castling him. He gets his bat down at the last possible moment. So cose. Paine then gets a couple through point from another delivery aimed in towards the stumps. Great spell, this. 48th over: Australia 107-5 (Smith 28, Paine 4) Smith pushes Archer to mid-on to begin, putting Paine in the firing line for the first time at this end. The skipper tries to pull but isn’t quick enough, edging into his pad - where is the short leg? Not there. But he keeps his cool, deflecting the next with soft hands well behind point for four to get off the mark. Australia are still 151 behind, it is worth remembering. 47th over: Australia 102-5 (Smith 27, Paine 0) Broad at the fresh man Paine, the captain having to defend on the line of his off stump four times before he’s given the chance to shoulder arms. Full and straight, Broad isn’t mucking around. Three maidens on the trot. 46th over: Australia 102-5 (Smith 27, Paine 0) It is dark again at Lord’s, the lights on full with Archer starting his fresh set. As I noted before, credit his way as well for Wade’s wicket, hitting him twice in his two previous overs. At Smith this time, he goes well beyond his outside edge playing off the back foot. Dangerous areas. Smith then has a pop at one that he would normally leave well alone, the bowler again winning the mini-battle. This is good stuff. The bouncer to finish is followed by Smith’s eyes all the way into Bairstow’s gloves, prompting more giggles. Find a telly, this is great entertainment. 45th over: Australia 102-5 (Smith 27, Paine 0) Broad has been rewarded for bowling such a full length - as Nasser Hussain notes on telly, fuller than at any stage in his career. As someone clever noted in the press box last week, professional athletes usually have to improve quite a lot at Broad’s age to stay relevant and that’s precisely what he’s done ahead of this summer. Paine is the new man, getting a nasty one to begin that jumps at his handle, the captain ripping his hand off the bat. He hates those, given the number of finger operations he’s required. Wicket maiden. Fantastic bowling! Broad brings Wade forward from around the wicket, tailing away from the left-hander. He finds the edge, just carrying to Burns at third slip. An excellent low catch. Wade, who looked so good before Archer roughed him up, is on his way. 44th over: Australia 102-4 (Smith 27, Wade 6) Ouch, Archer hits Wade again this time - this time on the shoulder. Smith dealt with him easily enough before taking one to mid-on, watching carefully. 43rd over: Australia 100-4 (Smith 26, Wade 6) Smith is making a habit of scoring behind square early in the over, helping Broad in that direction for Australia’s 100th run. Warm applause from the packed Lord’s crowd - they love their Saturdays at HQ. Wade is forced to use his bat in defence until the final ball, Broad from around the wicket hooping back a long way; not far from that off-stump with the No6 shouldering arms. Top notch cricket so far. “Sat in Jakarta airport after a combined 16 hours in transit,” Harry Coleman reports to me on twitter. “Can’t speak to much really but how about that The Shape of Water, hey? My vote for smoothest action goes to the big charming fish man.” Slept in the bath, you say, Smithy? Norwegian Wood, then. 42nd over: Australia 99-4 (Smith 25, Wade 6) Archer it is, replacing Stokes after just a couple of overs. He’s full to Smith immediately, clipping one to fine leg. Wade has to be right on it, under an accurate bumper then directing into his body at 90mph. He’s good enough to keep him out. Ooh, the last ball is a nasty one, hitting Wade on the fingers. He takes his glove off between overs to give his hand a shake. He hasn’t called for the medical staff, so that’s a good sign. 41st over: Australia 98-4 (Smith 24, Wade 6) Broad and Smith are both in the game here; a fantastic contest emerging early on this fourth day. To begin, the Australian hammers him through cover off the back foot for the second time so far - there wasn’t much wrong with that ball, either. The England attack-leader bounces back with the second delivery of the morning that’s good enough to beat Smith. A beauty, seaming up the slope. When Wade gets his turn, he drives a full delivery with lovely timing, beating mid-off. With it, the Tasmanian reaches 1000 Test Match runs. Nine off the over. “If Jardine were in charge he would place two very short legs in place (perhaps Stokes and Woakes) and thereby prevent Smith doing his waddle out to short leg,” suggests Will Buckley. “Get in his head, muck up his OCD routine and watch his mind unravel.” 40th over: Australia 89-4 (Smith 19, Wade 2) Probing over from Stokes, well watched initially by Wade who is later able to dig out a yorker down for one. Smith is happy enough jumping across his woodwork for another single to finish, tucking to fine leg. “Morning Adam.” G’day, Kim Thonger. “Sorry to start the day in disagreement but on the question of smoothness, everyone else is wrong. Tom Cartwright had by far the smoothest action and only missed out on more Test cricket because of moronic selection policy. Not a recent development obvs.” How about Jofra bowling 94mph bumpers yesterday? Doesn’t the radar slow most bowlers down when they dig in short? More! More! 39th over: Australia 87-4 (Smith 18, Wade 1) Smith beaten! Broad goes past his blade with his first ball of the morning - dare I say, a nervous prod? Sure enough, the former captain is furious at himself and shifts into light-sabre mode as the sun comes out from behind the clouds. What a glorious sight. Just on Smith’s odd habits when leaving the ball, he doesn’t do it all the time. As he’s explained when I’ve asked him about it before, this is a clue that he’s trying to shift into his highest level of concentration. With a bit of width, he pushes a boundary with ease through point off the back foot; so much time, lovely batting. He then defends the final ball and kicks his legs up like he’s setting up to take a diving catch - the crowd laugh as one. “Surplus energy,” says Ian Botham. Something like that. 38th over: Australia 82-4 (Smith 14, Wade 1) Ahh, that’s right: Ben Stokes had five balls remaining when the rain arrived two minutes before the lunch break yesterday. The first of those is to Wade, who clips one to get off the mark from the 24th ball he has faced. The Tasmanian did very nicely in tough conditions yesterday, reinforcing that his technique is a lot tighter than during his previous stints as a Test player. Smith’s turn and Stokes gets one to spit off a length, the Aussie master forced to rip his bottom hand off the blade. It doesn’t bother him too much though, getting his first run of the day from the next delivery, tucked neatly behind square. Good morning to you all! Thanks, JP! The players are on the field, Ben Stokes to begin from in front of my position at the Nursery End. Wade is the man on strike. We have 196 overs remaining in this Test Match. Bring it on. PLAY! Right, the players are making their way out to the middle so it’s time for me to stand aside and let Collo have an uninterrupted view of the middle. Thanks for having me, see you again tomorrow. We’re now just five minutes from the resumption of play. That means you should start sending your emails and tweets Adam Collins’s way because I will soon be off to put my feet up. Yes please! Andersonwatch update: “Richard Hadlee was the smoothest of all, surely,” emails Mike Herd, “with a word for Mike Hendrick too.” Just ten minutes or so until play resumes. Can England dismiss Smith cheaply and send a shockwave through the Australian dressing room? Here we go, Bharathan knows his Onions. Raymond Reardon (not that one), has turned up with the lols. “Smith, Warner and Bancroft would be the three smoothest woodworkers for using a fine 180 grit.” Thomas Hopkins likes a bit of rough. “I may be swimming against the tide here, but I rather enjoy a lack of smoothness, Jasprit Bumrah a current favourite player. There’s something delightfully contrary about his action.” When we talk smooth bowling actions we’re naturally drawn to pace, but what about SK Warne? Has there been a more fluid action in the game? Steve Smith doing Steve Smith things... Because we change writers during the day we will often receive emails intended for the person on deck long after we’ve logged off. Sometimes these provide obvious clues about what was being discussed in our absence, like Scott Roberts’s email titled “Getting Smith out”. (His answer, by the way, is “decide how we’re trying to get Smith out and stick to that plan”.) But on other occasions it is frankly impossible to imagine what on earth was going on. This morning, for example, I logged on to find an email from David Baker with the message “The Communards, Don’t leave me this way.” No idea what it was related to, but it’s a banger. A lovely interjection from Mr Naylor. Agree with a lot of this. Here’s an Allan Donald masterclass. Frantic yet smooth makes me think of the scene in 24 Hour Party People where Martin Hannett wants Joy Division to play “faster but slower”. Caddick was a beauty though. Very repeatable and consistent, but smoother than Archer? If there’s cricket news about Ali Martin will sniff it out. Like confirmation Olly Stone will miss the rest of the Ashes through injury. Overseas? Want to listen to TMS but can’t find it on your dial? Try this link, courtesy of Peter Crees. “I put forward Shane Bond in the smooth action category,” nominates Avitaj Mitra. “A pity his career was wrecked with injuries. The stats don’t do justice to the kind of bowler he was.” Superb bowler, but for me anyway not in the same class as someone like Holding for smoothness. Bond’s action is all about the effort in the snap of the delivery stride. Curtley’s a nice shout. I used to love how his smooth action concealed a Pythagorean use of angles. Here’s your day four deck. Will it prove treacherous enough to snare ten Englishmen or 16 Australians in the next two days? John Starbuck is quickest off the mark in the daily email race. Attracted to the blog by the lure of smooth. “Michael Holding, Malcolm Marshall and Richard Hadlee are top of my list,” John emails. “We shall have to wait a season or two before Jofra Archer finds his correct place in the Dean Martin Stakes.” Three superb bowlers, each with very different actions. For pure smooth though I’m leaning towards Holding. Andy Bull had the pleasure of filing his column on Jofra Archer. Question: where does Archer’s action rank on the all-time smoothness scale? We can have subcategories for contemporary and all-time comparison. Weather: The headline news is the forecast is dry for the remainder of the Test. Aside from that it should be around 20C for most of today but there’s a stiff south-westerly which should keep everyone in Lord’s on their toes. Already forgotten what happened yesterday? Fear not because Vic Marks didn’t miss a thing. This paragraph in particular captures the state of play. That outcome is still by no means guaranteed, however, and the captains will ensure none of the players is seduced into concluding the draw is inevitable – and with good reason. In the 21st century batsmen are less adept at batting out for a draw and there are still 196 overs available in the second Ashes Test. That’ll do. Hello everybody and welcome to the fourth day of the second Test from Lord’s. The good news is the rain has cleared and we’re set for a full day’s play. The bad news is, frankly, all over the place right now so let’s not dwell on that half of the aphorism and just enjoy the cricket, like this 24 carat nugget of pure joy. If that didn’t make you smile you’ve got a brick for a heart and we can’t be friends. I’ll be with you for the next hour or so but once play begins Adam Collins will shower you in text. If you want to join in this pre-play fun you can drop me an email or a tweet.
fields.bylineHtml: Tanya Aldred , Adam Collins and Jonathan Howcroft

webTitle: Wigging out: why drag is bigger and wilder than ever at Edinburgh

fields.headline: Wigging out: why drag is bigger and wilder than ever at Edinburgh
fields.standfirst: It used to be that just wearing a dress and lip-syncing was enough. But now drag is mainstream, the bar for this most creative and transgressive art form has been raised
fields.trailText: It used to be that just wearing a dress and lip-syncing was enough. But now drag is mainstream, the bar for this most creative and transgressive art form has been raised
fields.body:
It’s Friday night at the Edinburgh fringe. Artists are running all over town, weaving around drunk punters and through flooded streets to make their guest spots. In full drag is me, dragging a tent through the rain, my wig swiftly uncurling. I arrive 15 minutes before I am supposed to go on stage, as a guest in someone else’s show. Up there already is a comedian reading from a yellow piece of paper. Next up, a man walks on stage and reads from a white piece of paper. Then it’s my turn: while using two audience volunteers, I spend four minutes erecting a tent while altering the lyrics to a popular ballad, singing live, ad-libbing jokes, wearing a full face of makeup, heels and a wig, all while reinterpreting Susan Sontag’s wondrous (and perhaps problematic) Notes on Camp. All in a day’s work for a drag queen in 2019.

When I started drag 10 years ago, the act of raiding your local Primark (without a care in the world for the impending meteorological apocalypse) and sticking on a dress and a plastic wig was deemed radical. Although this practice had existed for hundreds of years – not the Primark bit, but the transgressing gender through dress bit – barely anyone had seen it before. But now, after a stiff cocktail of RuPaul’s Drag Race, social media and the increased acceptance of gender fluidity, there are countless queens out there with more followers than Jeremy Corbyn. Drag is everything the internet could want: colourful, uplifting, funny, beautiful, political, and the key to a wholly different way of life. And so, with more interest came more drag. And naturally, with more drag came higher expectations.

So, as queers have had to for centuries, we evolved: we went multi-genre. Genre-fluid, perhaps. Now there are drag performers who can do everything. I know drag artists who can do backflips while singing, who can sew a whole wardrobe, lip-sync the house down, gather entire communities in rural areas together and change people’s minds. Not to blow my own horn, but I can also make you laugh and cry and – as two people have told me this week – pack an emotional punch while also making you feel kind of turned on, all while hitting almost every note in Minnie Riperton’s perfect Loving You.

A friend of mine, the brilliant queen Ginger Johnson, who is at the fringe with her show Happy Place, attributes the increasing performance dexterity we now see in drag to our widening cultural diet. “Drag has always been a pastiche of mainstream contemporary culture,” Ginger explains. “Digital life has seen that mainstream broaden, so drag has had to do the same. I think there are also just a lot more queens around than there used to be, which is bringing a lot more cultural influences into the art form. And that can only be a good thing.” Being asked to broaden our practice is no bad thing: it makes our performances richer and more textured.

But it also becomes somewhat complicated to know what’s expected of us, too. Spellbinding drag prinx and scene legend Chiyo says they often turn up to gigs and aren’t sure what they should be offering. “Last week I almost did two upbeat, almost nude burlesque numbers to a room of five people in prime daylight in Brighton. It wasn’t until I actually got to the space that I realised they probably wanted me to do an artist talk and/or some spoken word.”

We must ask why have expectations for us been raised, when expectations for the dominant voices in entertainment – for example those two boys with their pieces of paper – remain the same.

Jodi Mitchell, or John Travulva depending on the time of day, is a brilliant drag king and standup who is co-founder of the side-splitting collective The LOL Word. “Every time I perform standup in drag, I have to dissect ‘the point’ of my set – whether there is one or not. Audience members sometimes invent excellent ones for me. I suspect this is because, subconsciously, they know that without there being a message, the point of the performance would just be that I am funny. It would be far too empowering for a non-binary person dressed as a man to just be funny, like male standups are. That would be truly terrifying.”

Of course, people who are single-genre should be celebrated for absolutely killing it in their chosen space, especially if they’re really bloody good, but I want to endlessly fanfare the brilliance of queens, kings, prinxs, inbetweeners who get up there and give us, literally, everything. Those who stand up on stage and subvert gender stereotypes, deconstruct power systems through jokes, mine their trauma, cover it in glitter, sing a cappella, all while doing a dance routine with a death drop. These people don’t simply comment on what they see, they offer entirely new ways of seeing it – and that’s real magic.

Now I don’t want to be a standup. I love the creativity and means of expression drag offers us. But often it can feel like all this skill is filed under “drag” and then chucked in a basement somewhere. But drag performers are stars, deeply skilled at many things because they have to be. It would be so wonderful for that to be celebrated by more than just a yasss queen.

  • Crystal Rasmussen presents The Bible 2 (Plus a Cure for Shame, Violence, Betrayal and Athlete’s Foot) Live! is at the Underbelly, Edinburgh, until 25 August
